course.title: Robotics
course.shortDescription: Hands-on introduction to building, programming, and controlling robots.
course.longDescription: Coverage of mechanical design, electronics, sensing, control, kinematics, robot programming, ROS, mobile robots, manipulators, computer vision, autonomy, safety, ethics, and competition prep.
course.audience: High school to early undergraduate; no prior robotics required; basic algebra and programming recommended.
outcomes: Describe and differentiate core robot subsystems (mechanical, electrical, sensing, control)
Implement closed-loop control for a differential-drive mobile robot
Tune a PID controller and justify parameter choices
Model forward kinematics for a 2-DOF arm
Apply basic inverse kinematics to reach a target pose
Integrate IMU + encoder fusion for improved heading estimation
Build a finite state machine to coordinate robot behaviors
Use ROS nodes and topics to publish/subscribe sensor and actuator data
Simulate a mobile robot and validate path following in a sandbox environment
Develop simple computer vision pipelines (thresholding, edges, feature tracking)
Explain and apply safety rules and fail-safes in robot design
Plan and execute a competition-ready strategy with testing and iteration

modules.title: Foundations
modules.summary: Robot types, components, coordinate frames, and core concepts.

glossary.definition: Device that converts energy to motion (e.g., motor).
Device that measures physical quantities (e.g., IMU).
Reference axes used to describe positions and orientations.
Degrees of freedom available for robot movement.
Structural framework of a robot.
Position and orientation of a robot or part.
Tool attached to a robot arm for interacting with environment.
Ability to operate independently without human intervention.
Control without feedback.
Control using feedback signals.

practice: Identify subsystems on a sample robot
Define local vs global frames for a mobile robot

lessons.title: Robot Types & Subsystems
objectives: By the end, students can list major robot classes and subsystems
By the end, students can describe roles of actuators and sensors

assessments.prompt: Which is an example of a robot actuated joint?
Explain why coordinate frames are essential in robotics and give an example.

lessons.title: Coordinate Frames
objectives: By the end, students can define pose and express positions in local frames
By the end, students can translate between local and global coordinates

assessments.prompt: Define pose and distinguish between position and orientation.

modules.title: Mechanics
modules.summary: Forces, torque, gear ratios, drivetrains, and chassis design.

glossary.definition: Rotational force causing angular acceleration.
Ratio of driven to driving gear teeth.
Lost motion due to gaps between gear teeth.
Condition where motor cannot rotate under load.
Grip between wheels and ground.

practice: Compute torque and speed trade-offs for a gearbox
Design a stable chassis layout for a given payload

lessons.title: Torque & Speed Trade-offs
objectives: By the end, students can explain torque-speed curves
By the end, students can select gear ratios for a target performance

assessments.prompt: Which setup increases torque?

lessons.title: Chassis Design
objectives: By the end, students can propose chassis designs minimizing backlash and maximizing traction

assessments.prompt: Propose a chassis design for uneven terrain and justify component choices.

modules.title: Electronics
modules.summary: Power, motors (DC, servo, stepper), drivers, PWM.

glossary.definition: Pulse width modulation for controlling motor speed.
Motor driver enabling bidirectional control.
Electronic speed controller for brushless motors.

lessons.title: Power & Drivers
objectives: By the end, students can wire a DC motor with an H-bridge and explain PWM control

assessments.prompt: PWM controls motor speed by?

lessons.title: Motor Types
objectives: By the end, students can compare DC, servo, and stepper motors for task suitability

assessments.prompt: Contrast servo vs stepper control characteristics.

glossary.definition: Inertial measurement unit measuring acceleration and rotation.
Sensor measuring rotational position or speed.
Light detection and ranging for distance measurement.

lessons.title: IMU & Encoders
objectives: By the end, students can integrate IMU and encoders for heading estimation

assessments.prompt: Describe a fusion approach combining IMU yaw rates and wheel encoders.

lessons.title: Range Sensors
objectives: By the end, students can evaluate ultrasonic vs LiDAR for obstacle detection

assessments.prompt: LiDAR provides?

modules.title: Control
modules.summary: Open vs closed loop, PID, tuning methods.

glossary.definition: Proportional-Integral-Derivative control method.
Scaling factor in control law.

lessons.title: Open vs Closed Loop
objectives: By the end, students can contrast open vs closed loop control

assessments.prompt: Give an example of closed-loop speed control.

lessons.title: PID Tuning
objectives: By the end, students can tune PID gains and justify choices

assessments.prompt: Explain a PID tuning strategy and stability considerations.

lessons.title: Python Basics for Robotics
objectives: By the end, students can implement an event loop

assessments.prompt: Write a loop reacting to sensor events.

lessons.title: Finite State Machines
objectives: By the end, students can design and implement a simple FSM

assessments.prompt: Draw an FSM for a line-following robot and implement transitions.

modules.title: Kinematics
modules.summary: Forward/inverse for mobile robots and simple arms.

lessons.title: Differential Drive Kinematics
objectives: By the end, students can model differential drive motion

assessments.prompt: Derive the relationship between wheel speeds and robot velocity.

lessons.title: 2-DOF Arm Kinematics
objectives: By the end, students can compute forward kinematics for a 2-DOF arm

assessments.prompt: Compute the end-effector pose for given joint angles.

modules.title: ROS Basics
modules.summary: Nodes, topics, messages; simulated environment intro.

lessons.title: ROS Nodes & Topics
objectives: By the end, students can publish/subscribe to topics

assessments.prompt: Explain how messages are passed in ROS.

lessons.title: Simulation Intro
objectives: By the end, students can run a robot in simulation

assessments.prompt: Set up a simulation and validate path following.

lessons.title: Path Following
objectives: By the end, students can implement a simple path follower

assessments.prompt: Design a controller for following a set of waypoints.

lessons.title: Grasping Basics
objectives: By the end, students can evaluate grasp strategies for objects

assessments.prompt: Compare pinch vs power grasp for sample tasks.

modules.title: Vision
modules.summary: Thresholding, edge detection, simple feature tracking.

lessons.title: Thresholding & Edges
objectives: By the end, students can implement basic thresholding and edge detection

assessments.prompt: Write code to threshold and detect edges in a sample image.

lessons.title: Feature Tracking
objectives: By the end, students can track simple features across frames

assessments.prompt: Explain the trade-offs of simple vs advanced tracking methods.

lessons.title: Localization Concepts
objectives: By the end, students can explain basic localization and mapping approaches

assessments.prompt: Discuss the role of sensor fusion in localization.

lessons.title: Behavior Trees
objectives: By the end, students can design a behavior tree for a scenario

assessments.prompt: Build a behavior tree for a search-and-rescue task.

lessons.title: Operating Safety
objectives: By the end, students can list safety rules and fail-safes

assessments.prompt: Explain why fail-safes are essential in robot design.

lessons.title: Ethics in Robotics
objectives: By the end, students can discuss responsible robotics design principles

assessments.prompt: Discuss ethical considerations in autonomous systems deployment.

lessons.title: Strategy & Testing
objectives: By the end, students can plan a competition strategy and testing regimen

assessments.prompt: Outline a test plan covering mechanical, electrical, and software subsystems.

standards.ENG-Mechanics-01: Apply fundamentals of forces, torque, and mechanical power.
standards.ENG-Software-02: Design state machines and control loops with justifications.
standards.ENG-Sensing-03: Integrate and interpret sensor data (IMU, encoder, range sensors).
